title: Essential oil
description: An essential oil is a concentrate of the aroma compound(s) of a plant. They are so named because they contain the "essence" of the plant's smell, and not because they are "essential" to human health.
cleaned_text: Essential oil [Jump to navigation](#mw-head) [Jump to search](#searchInput) |Against allopathy| An essential oil is a concentrate of the [aroma compound(s)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/aroma_compound) of a plant. They are so named because they contain the "essence" of the plant's smell, and not because they are "essential" to human health. Usage and efficacy[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Essential_oil&action=edit§ion=1)] Not woo[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Essential_oil&action=edit§ion=2)] Note that these products are sometimes advertised as having woo effects other than listed below. [Camphor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camphor), [eucalyptol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/eucalyptol), [menthol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/menthol), [eugenol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/eugenol)and [methyl salicylate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/methyl_salicylate)are a category of chemicals found in essential oils like mint, clove and wintergreen. They are decent topical analgesics and moderately effective decongestants, because they produce a cold sensation, particularly in the lungs when inhaled, due to their action on ion channels in tissue. They are also used to flavor food and [tobacco](/wiki/Tobacco)products, but they are toxic in large doses. [Citronella oil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citronella_oil), distilled from Cymbopogon spp. (lemongrass), is a decent insect repellent. [Thymol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thymol)is found in thyme and many other essential oils. It is used to treat helminth infections and is also a decent pesticide. - Refined [limonene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/limonene), found in citrus oil, is an excellent degreaser for metal automotive/appliance parts in low concentrations, and a decent paint stripper in high concentrations. Also used as an insecticide because it's very toxic. [Linalool](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linalool)is an important chemical intermediate in the production of vitamin E. It's also an effective pesticide against flies and cockroaches (but not mosquitoes). [Witch hazel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witch_hazel)is an essential oil that produces a pleasant astringent sensation when applied topically and has a moderate antiseptic effect. Maybe pinenes, cineoles and alcohols that give it a fresh, cooling scent. It's a decent decongestant when inhaled and shows some promise as a topical antiseptic, but studies are inconclusive. However, it's toxic in large doses, can cause serious allergic reactions, and it's less effective than options that are a fraction of the cost. But it does smell... really nice... or like a toilet cake (depending on who you ask). Mostly/entirely woo[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Essential_oil&action=edit§ion=4)] [Alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine)is big on essential oils for all kinds of nonsense uses, many of which are very dangerous. Have a look at our [list of medicinal plants](/wiki/List_of_medicinal_plants)for examples of specific plants. - Anything from [Young Living](/wiki/Young_Living)or their bastard stepchild doTerra. [Aromatherapy](/wiki/Aromatherapy)often uses essential oils because they're concentrated (more smell = more health). - In the panchakarma practice of the [pseudoscience](/wiki/Pseudoscience)known as [Ayurvedic medicine](/wiki/Ayurvedic_medicine), patients are made to ingest the (sometimes quite toxic) essential oils. Safety and adverse effects[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Essential_oil&action=edit§ion=5)] Essential oils are highly concentrated mixtures of [chemicals](/wiki/Chemistry). They can potentially cause an allergic reaction or be toxic in large doses. Some essential oils can consist primarily of a single chemical compound. For example, mustard oil can consist of up to 92% allyl isothiocyanate [[1]](#cite_note-1) (>90% is usually considered a technical grade, the lowest commercial purity offered by chemical companies). Essential oils are applied in one of three ways: the [English](/wiki/English) school of diluting in vegetable oil and massaging on the body (topical), the French school of ingestion, or the German school of inhalation. [[2]](#cite_note-desk-2) [[3]](#cite_note-3) From a toxicological perspective, these three routes of administration range from lowest risk (topical) to highest risk (inhalation) for adverse effects for the same compound and dosage. Because essential oils are concentrated, they have an increased risk of adverse effects compared to the herbs from which they were derived. The big problem is that believers in "alternative medicine" tend to believe that essential oils are devoid of potential for harm because they're ["natural"](/wiki/Appeal_to_nature). This has led to some people dying or falling ill as a result of using them. [[4]](#cite_note-posadzki-4) One woman suffered second- and third-degree burns after applying doTerra essential oil before getting in a tanning bed. [[5]](#cite_note-5) Essential oils may often be labeled as cosmetic goods, freeing them of the obligation of at least some countries' federal regulations. [[6]](#cite_note-6) This exemption can vary by country and by the claims made by the specific retailer, but at least in the US, anyone can sell an essential oil by itself along with a [Quack Miranda Warning](/wiki/Quack_Miranda_Warning), even potentially toxic oils like bitter almond oil. [[7]](#cite_note-7) Unprocessed bitter almond oil can be >95% benzaldehyde, [[8]](#cite_note-8) but it also contains the poison cyanide. [[9]](#cite_note-9) Other examples of toxic effects from essential oils are: [[10]](#cite_note-10) - Camphor (Cinnamomum camphora): can cause seizures if swallowed, has caused seizures in children when applied topically - Eucalyptus (Eucalyptus spp.): can cause seizures if swallowed - Nutmeg (Myristica fragrans): can cause hallucinations if swallowed - Pennyroyal (Mentha pulegium): a liver toxin - Sage (Salvia spp.): swallowing more than a small amount can cause seizures - Turpentine (extracted from the resin of various trees): can cause "irritation eyes, skin, nose, throat; headache, dizziness, convulsions; skin sensitization; hematuria (blood in the urine), proteinuria; kidney damage; abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, liquid)" [[11]](#cite_note-11) - Wintergreen (Gaultheria procumbens): can be lethal if consumed in amounts larger than is allowed as a food additive A review of adverse effects from essential oils used in aromatherapy reported a total of 71 adverse events. [[4]](#cite_note-posadzki-4) The adverse effects primarily consisted of dermatitis, but included one death (from wintergreen oil). [[4]](#cite_note-posadzki-4) (Cananga odorata) were the most common oils associated with adverse events. [[4]](#cite_note-posadzki-4) Additionally, 5 deaths have been associated extracts. [[12]](#cite_note-12) [[13]](#cite_note-13) [[14]](#cite_note-14) [[15]](#cite_note-15) [[16]](#cite_note-16) Some books have recommended treatment of serious diseases with essential oils (e.g., [cancer](/wiki/Cancer), bacterial pneumonia, arteriosclerosis, and high blood pressure). [[2]](#cite_note-desk-2) [[17]](#cite_note-17) This is particularly problematic when the disease sufferer forgoes safe and effective medical treatment (i.e. medical treatment whose risk vs. benefit has been evaluated) for what are likely to be ineffective essential oils that may or may not be safe. Crank magnetism[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Essential_oil&action=edit§ion=6)] Essential oil usage can be a focal point for [crank magnetism](/wiki/Crank_magnetism). For example, the 3rd edition of the Essential Oils Desk Reference [[2]](#cite_note-desk-2) uses [testimonials](/wiki/Testimonials) and [appeal to [Hildegard of Bingen](/wiki/Hildegard_of_Bingen)) for justification. [[2]](#cite_note-desk-2) The book describes using essential oils in conjunction with foot [reflexology](/wiki/Reflexology), [acupuncture](/wiki/Acupuncture), the is against [water chlorination](/wiki/Water_chlorination) [[2]](#cite_note-desk-2) despite it having been shown to be a safe and effective means of disease prevention. [[18]](#cite_note-18) The book also tacitly supports the [antivax](/wiki/Antivax) movement by describing treatments for commonly preventable childhood diseases, which no child should need unless they weren't getting vaccinated (e.g., diphtheria, whooping cough, [measles](/wiki/Measles), mumps, chicken pox, and yes, even polio!). [[2]](#cite_note-desk-2) Some of the crankier ideas in the 3rd edition were probably removed from later editions of the book after the publisher closed down and sold publishing rights and back stock [[19]](#cite_note-19) to Life Science Publishing, [[20]](#cite_note-20) though the older editions remain popular. [[21]](#cite_note-21) Mormonism[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Essential_oil&action=edit§ion=7)] There is some confluence of [Mormonism](/wiki/Mormonism), [multilevel marketing](/wiki/Multilevel_marketing) (MLM), and essential oils. This could be based on several factors: - Olive oil is used for [anointing](/wiki/Anointing)in the Mormon church [[22]](#cite_note-22) - Herbs are mentioned in the Mormon [Doctrine and Covenants](/wiki/Doctrine_and_Covenants)for [healing](/wiki/Healing) [[23]](#cite_note-23) - The apparent propensity for Mormons to engage in MLM schemes. [[24]](#cite_note-24) - Use of essential oils by Mormon women may be a means for them to attain power via healing within the Church, since women are not allowed into the priesthood. [[25]](#cite_note-25) [[26]](#cite_note-26) Examples include: - dTERRA oil company [[27]](#cite_note-27) [Young Living](/wiki/Young_Living)Essential Oils — an MLM essential oil company Lehi, [Utah](/wiki/Utah)(a city that is 89% Mormon). [[28]](#cite_note-28) [[29]](#cite_note-29)Young Living got into an odd legal battle with dTERRA in 2014 over mutual allegations of adulteration with synthetic chemicals. [[30]](#cite_note-30) [[31]](#cite_note-31) In 2014, dTERRA and Young Living Essential Oils were warned by the [FDA](/wiki/FDA) against making unsubstantiated medical claims for treatment of diseases. [[32]](#cite_note-32) dTERRA was accused of unsubstantiated claims for treatment of " [viral](/wiki/Viral) infections (including [ebola](/wiki/Ebola)), [bacterial](/wiki/Bacteria) infections, cancer, brain injury, [autism](/wiki/Autism), endometriosis, Grave's Disease, Alzheimer's Disease, tumor reduction, [ADD/ADHD](/wiki/Attention-deficit_hyperactivity_disorder), and other conditions that are not amenable to [self-diagnosis](/wiki/Self-diagnosis) and treatment by individuals who are not medical practitioners." [[33]](#cite_note-33) Young Living was accused of unsubstantiated claims for treatment of "viral infections (including ebola), Parkinson's disease, autism, diabetes, hypertension, cancer, insomnia, heart disease, [post-traumatic stress disorder](/wiki/Post-traumatic_stress_disorder) (PTSD), dementia, and multiple sclerosis..."
